RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

During  the  last  decade,  Viet  Nam  has  made  remarkable  progress  towards  the 
2. 
achievement  of  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs).  Viet  Nam  has  already  achieved 
several MDGs, including those for poverty and child health, and is well on its way to achieving 
others. Infant mortality fell by nearly 28% from 58 per 1,000 live births in 1990 to 42 per 1,000 
live births in 2000. Maternal mortality decreased by 50% from about 200 per 100,000 live births 
in 1990 to about 100 per 100,000 live births in 2000. Access to reproductive health services, as 
measured by tetanus toxoid immunization, has increased from 71.7% in 1997 to 82.9% in 2001. 
Impressive achievements have also been made in controlling communicable diseases including 
malaria and tuberculosis. The only MDG that poses a challenge is the controlling and reversing 
the spread of HIV/AIDS.2 
 
3. 
The Government has a strong policy and institutional structure to support primary health 
care, which has evolved over the last few years to pay greater attention to the needs of the poor 
and  disadvantaged.  The  Government  has  recently  launched  a  major  policy  initiative3  called 
Prime Minister’s Decision 139, which is designed to ensure access to basic health care for the 
poor.  According  to  this  new  policy,  provincial  peoples’  committees  will  establish  Health  Care 
Funds for the Poor (HCFP)4 to help those living in poor communes and selected ethnic minority 
communities gain access to the public health system. The Government has earmarked annual 
funding  of  about  $50  million  for  HCFP,  which  demonstrates  its  commitment  to  improving  the 
health  status  of  the  poor  and  ethnic  minorities.  There  has  been  a  greater  emphasis  on 
decentralizing  the  management  and  provision  of  health  services  in  recent  years.  A  recent 
significant  policy  measure5  covers  all  revenue-raising  public  enterprises  and  public  service 
entities.  The  measure  aims  to  improve  the  quality  of  public  services  by  making  entities  and 
agencies  financially  autonomous,  and  encouraging  them  to  take  initiative  in  determining  staff 
numbers, compensation, and use.

services at the district level require considerable strengthening. For most people living in rural 
areas, the district health centers (DHCs) are the first level of referral care and comprehensive 
curative services. The Government plans to strengthen health facilities at this level throughout

8. 
The  recently  implemented  Decision  139  provides  further  justification  for  strengthening 
district-level health infrastructure. This initiative will reduce financial constraints on using health 
services and is likely to significantly increase the use of district health services by the poor and 
ethnic minorities. Use of health services, particularly inpatient services, has already increased in 
most  provinces  since  the  adoption  of  Decision  139.  With  full  implementation  of  Decision  139 
and  wider  dissemination  of  information  about  its  benefits,  utilization  of  health  services  will 
increase  even  more.  Existing  capacity  at  the  district  level  will  be  insufficient  to  cope  with  the 
increased  demand.  Some  40%  of  the  population  in  the  Central  Highlands  will  benefit  from 
Decision 139 because the region has a high incidence of poverty and a large number of ethnic 
minorities. The existing capacity of the region’s district health system is  already stretched and 
will not be able to effectively meet increased demand. 
 
9. 
The capacity of inpatient wards to meet the increased demand is the biggest constraint 
on  DHCs.  Some  DHCs  require  upgrading  or  expansion.  Others  will  need  to  be  moved  and 
rebuilt  in  more  accessible  areas.  Current  district  facilities  have  poor  water  supply,  sanitation, 
and solid waste disposal. Medical equipment also needs considerable support, both to replace 
old  and  outdated  equipment  and  to  upgrade  the  quality  of  service.  Imaging  and  diagnostic 
equipment are particular concerns in most district facilities. 

 
2. 

Human Resources 

 
10. 
Both  quality  and  quantity  of  health  personnel  constrain  services  in  the  region.  The 
Central Highlands have about 10% fewer health personnel per capita. Given the low population 
density  and  large  geographical  distances,  fewer  staff  significantly  affect  services,  particularly 
outreach. The quality of health care providers is also much poorer in the Central Highlands than 
in the rest of the country.  
 
11. 
The  region  faces  the  twin  challenge  of  (i)  upgrading  the  technical  skills  of  health 
professionals,  and  (ii)  ensuring  continued  maintenance  of  applied  skills.  Lack  of  skills  is 
particularly  acute  for  medical  doctors  in  the  areas  of  surgery,  obstetrics,  pediatrics,  internal 
medicine, infectious diseases, and public health. Basic health care is difficult to provide at the 
district  level  in  the  absence  of  specialized  doctors.  There  is  also  a  need  to  train  health  care 
providers  who  speak  the  local  language.  Improving  frontline  primary  care  services  are  is  also 
needed  to  improve  quality  of  care  at  the  commune  and  district  levels.  Strengthening  the 
capacity  of  secondary  medical  schools,  responsible  for  providing  primary  pre-service  and  in-
service training, is also required to improve quality of clinical health services. 
 

3. 

Demand for Health Services 

 
12. 
Lack of affordability is the major demand-side constraint for the poor in accessing health 
services.  Decision  139  is  a  bold  initiative  taken  to  address  this  constraint  for  the  poor  and 
disadvantaged  populations  through  the  establishment  of  the  HCFP.  This  will  help  improve  the 
health  status  of  the  poor  by  increasing  their  access  to  and  utilization  of  health  services.  It  will 
also  potentially  reduce  the  impact  of  high  out-of-pocket  health  care  expenses  on  household 
budgets.  Promising  as  it  is,  the  success  of  the  policy  initiative  cannot  be  taken  for  granted. 

 

  4

Success  of  Decision  139  will  depend  on  the  ability  of  the  Government  and  provinces  to  (i) 
allocate  sufficient  resources;  (ii)  establish  mechanisms  and  guidelines  for  allocating  and 
managing  funds,  benefit  packages,  and  payments  to  providers;  (iii)  develop  a  transparent 
system  for  identifying  beneficiaries;  (iv)  empower  beneficiaries  to  expect  and  demand  the 
intended services; and (v) institutionalize a system of monitoring, supervision, and evaluation of 
the  implementation  and  impact  of  Decision  139.  Support  is  needed  for  these  aspects  of  the 
initiative. 
 
Cultural  and  language  barriers  are  another  challenge  for  making  health  services  more 
13. 
accessible to the poor, especially ethnic minority groups. Health promotion and prevention will 
become increasingly more important as the burden of disease changes from communicable to 
the noncommunicable diseases. This will require significant changes in the materials developed 
for  information,  education,  and  communication  (IEC)  and  in  the  ways  health  messages  are 
disseminated.  This  will  entail  greater  community  involvement  in  providing  and  monitoring 
services,  and  more  culturally  sensitive  health  promotion  and  behavior  change  communication 
(BCC) programs.

15. 
The  project  design  is  based  on  an  extensive  review  of  health  needs  and  investment 
options in the Central Highlands. The Project was developed in consultation with the Ministry of 
Health  (MOH),  provincial  and  district  authorities,  communities,  and  international  agencies 
working in the health sector. The Project has the following three components: 
 

1. 

Upgrading Facilities and Equipment 

 
16. 
The  Project  will  focus  on  improving  the  quality  of  care  and  utilization  of  services  that 
address the immediate health needs of the rural population. It will also strengthen the capacity 
of the provincial health system to meet the increased demand for health services stemming from 
the implementation of Decision 139. The Project will ensure that these services are sustainable. 
 
17. 
Curative  Health  Services.  The  major  focus  will  be  on  strengthening  the  DHCs,  which 
often represent the first level of care in the community. People living in rural and remote areas 
often seek curative services from these health centers. The DHCs include inpatient, diagnostic, 
and  treatment  facilities,  as  well  as  other  clinical  support  facilities.  The  Project  will  also

varies  from  the  center  to  center  and  is  based  on  the  needs  and  projected  utilization  of  the 
center. In 13 DHCs, support will be provided for new facilities and upgrading of inpatient wards, 
technical blocks, solid waste management, and water and sanitation systems. Support for solid 
waste management and water, and sanitation systems will also be provided in 2 DHCs. 
 
19. 
The Project will also finance the procurement of appropriate equipment for 16 DHCs to 
improve service quality. The new equipment will (i) replace old and non-functioning equipment; 
or  (ii)  upgrade  technology  for  existing  procedures;  or  (iii)  seek  to  provide  new  services.  The 
Project  will  ensure  that  health  personnel  are  properly  trained  to  use  the  equipment,  and 
operational  manuals  are  supplied  in  Vietnamese.  The  Government  has  provided  assurances 
that  equipment  will  be  maintained  during  and  beyond  the  project  period  through  adequate 
increases in operation and maintenance budgets. 
 
20. 
The  Project  will  also  provide  some  limited  support  for  a  provincial  hospital  in  Dak  Lak, 
which  is  becoming  a  regional  hospital  to  support  the  tertiary  health  care  needs  for  the  entire 
Central Highlands. It will act as a model for health services and will provide training for health 
care  providers  in  the  region.  The  Government  largely  finances  the  hospital.  The  Project  will 
support the procurement of its medical equipment. The Project will also support strengthening of 
the referral system and networking between provinces and the hospital.

Strengthening Financing and Management 

 
30. 
The  Project  will  support  MOH  and  the  provincial  departments  of  health  in  effectively 
implementing  Decision  139,  and  improving  the  management  information  system  (MIS)  and 
surveillance of communicable and noncommunicable diseases.  
 
31. 
Effective  implementation  of  Decision  139  poses  a  considerable  challenge  since  the 
proportion of poor in the Central Highlands is greater than any other region of the country. There 
are  about  1.7  million  people  in  the  region—about  40%  of  the  Central  Highlands’  total 
population—eligible  for  subsidized  services.  Through  financing  from  Sida,  the  Project  will 
institutionalize  mechanisms  for  effective  monitoring,  supervision,  and  evaluation  of  both  the 
implementation  and  impact  of  the  HCFP.  The  Project  will  also  finance  part  of  the  provincial 
contribution  to  HCFP  based  on  criteria  determined  during  implementation.  The  Project  will 
support  development  of  an  information  system  to  monitor  the  use  of  services  at  both  the 
provincial  and  national  levels.  At  the  provincial  level,  it  will  also  finance  regular  household 
surveys to assess the impact on the use of services and out-of-pocket expenditures by the poor. 
 
32. 
The  Project  will  document  and  disseminate  the  effectiveness  of  targeting  intended 
beneficiaries and implementation experience through specially sponsored studies. Lessons from 
the  Central  Highlands  will  be  useful  in  fine-tuning  the  implementation  of  Decision  139  in  the 
whole country. The Project will also provide selected support for national implementation. 
 
33. 
The  Project  will  strengthen  the  MIS  in  the  four  provinces  with  a  view  to  strengthening 
supervision and management of health services. Improved MIS will also provide critical, timely 
information about incidence and prevalence of communicable and noncommunicable diseases. 
The Project will also support training at all levels to strengthen management. The focus at the 
commune  and  district  levels  is  (i)  improving  supervision  of  technical  care,  (ii)  strengthening 
planning and organization of care, and (iii) enhancing financial sustainability of facilities. 
 
34. 
The Project will help strengthen the capacity of MOH and provincial health departments 
to implement the project by supporting a project management unit (PMU) and provincial project 
management units (PPMUs). The Project will finance the necessary equipment and consulting 
services required for effective implementation, monitoring, and evaluation of project activities.

The  Project  will  improve  the  availability  and  appropriateness  of  quality  health  services,

public  health  system  in  the  central  highland  provinces.  During  project  preparation,  a  needs

c. 

HIV/AIDS  

 
40. 
HIV/AIDS poses a special threat to populations, especially ethnic minority groups, in the 
Central Highlands. Current estimates show that 21 per 100,000 people in the Central Highlands 
are infected with the disease, compared to 56 per 100,000 nationwide. The populations in the 
Central Highlands are relatively isolated from mainstream society, which offers some protection 
from  infection  but  also  impedes  education  and  prevention  programs.  For  ethnic  minorities  in 
particular,  cultural  and  language  barriers  may  also  limit  access  to  materials  and  information, 
thereby increasing the risk of infection and vulnerability of marginalized populations. The Project 
will help to strengthen current efforts to prevent the spread of HIV/AIDS through the preventive 
health  infrastructure  and  health  promotion  programs  specifically  targeted  at  HIV/AIDS. 
HIV/AIDS activities will be mainstreamed through training project staff and construction workers.

design  and  does  not  harm  any  specific  group.  The  Project  will  benefit  close  to  1.5  million 
members  of  ethnic  minorities  in  the  four  central  highland  provinces.  An  ethnic  minority 
development  plan  has  been  prepared  to  highlight  project  benefits  to  ethnic  minority 
communities, and ensure they have access to affordable, high-quality health services in a more 
equitable health system (Appendix 6).

Gender 

The  Project  fully  mainstreams  gender  concerns  into  its  design  to  ensure  that  women 
42. 
share proportionately in project benefits. The Project aims to improve and raise the health status 
of about 2.2 million women, including 800,000 ethnic minority women. The Project emphasizes 
women’s health, particularly in the areas of reproductive health, obstetrics, gynecological care, 
and maternal and child health. Improved access to reproductive health services will prevent half 
of the current maternal deaths per year by the end of the Project, and significantly increase the 
proportion of deliveries in the region receiving improved pre- and postnatal care. The Project will 
reduce the burden of disease for women, and help increase women’s social contribution to their 
families  and  communities.  A  gender  strategy  has  been  prepared  to  ensure  that  women  have 
increased access to and utilization of affordable and high-quality health services (Appendix 7).

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

 
A. 

Project Benefits 

63. 
The Project will have a significant impact on the health and well-being of the population 
in  the  Central  Highlands.  Since  health  is  closely  related  to  productivity,  it  will  also  have  an 
indirect impact on income. The Project will directly reduce poverty incidence by reducing out-of-
pocket  expenditure  on  health  by  the  poor  and  near-poor,  and  providing  financial  protection 
against catastrophic health conditions. The efficiency and productivity of the health sector in the 
region will also be improved (see Appendix 16 for details).  
 
Improved  Health  Status.  The  Project  will  benefit  4.4  million  people  in  the  Central 
64. 
Highlands through improved quality of, and access to, health services. These benefits will target 
a  rural  population  of  3.2  million,  particularly  the  1  million  poorest  and  1.5  million  ethnic 
minorities. The Project will reduce the excess burden of disease in the Central Highlands and 
bring it in line with the national averages. It will also help the provinces achieve the health sector 
targets set in the Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy. The infant mortality 
rate will fall from 64 per 1,000 live births now to 40 per 1,000 live births in 2008, the maternal 
mortality  ratio  will  drop  from  170  per  100,000  live  births  to  110  per  100,000  live  births,  and 
coverage of prenatal care will rise from 70% to 90%. 
 
65. 
Poverty  Reduction  and  Increased  Equity.  The  Project  will  support  the  government’s 
decision to fully finance health insurance for the Central Highlands’ poor, or to reimburse them 
for  health  services.  This  will  reduce  out-of-pocket  expenses  on  health  care  and  free  up 
resources for other expenses such as food and housing. This pro-poor health financing will also 
make  the  health  care  payment  less  regressive,  and  will  protect  the  poor  against  catastrophic 
health outcomes, a frequent cause of destitution and deep poverty. 
 
66. 
Increased  Effectiveness  and  Efficiency  of  the  Health  System.  Improved  quality  of 
health care services, increased efficiency in health care delivery, and increased staff knowledge 
and skills will increase the overall efficiency of the health care system in the Central Highlands. 
The  Project  will  improve  the  effectiveness  and  efficiency  of  the  health  system  in  the  four 
provinces  with  the  measures  of  upgrading  health  facilities  and  preventive  health  centers, 
strengthening  training  and  management  capacity,  and  increasing  the  quality  of  health  service 
delivery. The district levels will emphasize improving of quality health care provision and service 
delivery.  The  project  will  also  establish  appropriate  planning  and  management  procedures  at 
provincial,  district,  and  commune  levels  with  trained  staff  to  ensure  the  sustainability  of  the 
effective and efficient health system.

of the population, including the poor and vulnerable. The Project will support technologies and

11.  Medical  solid  waste—glassware,  syringes,  dressings,  bandages,  plasters,  plastic

geographical remoteness of health centers, and (iv) high cost of treatment systems.

Opportunity Cost of Seeking Health Services 

 

6. 
The opportunity cost of seeking health care is high for the poor, and prevents them from 
utilizing  high-quality  health  care.6  Many  women  often  lack  control  over  household  income. 
Insufficient  time  and  money  limit  their  ability  to  make  timely  decisions  about  health  care  for 
themselves  and  their  children.  Heavy  domestic  and  productive  workloads  also  prevent  poor 
women  from  seeking  early  health  care  and  treatment.  With  an  increase  in  economic 
opportunities, the opportunity cost of inactivity is too high for poor women, especially for ethnic 
minority  women.  Based  on  the  1992-1993  and  1997-1998  Viet  Nam  Living  Standard  Surveys, 
poor  pregnant  women  and  mothers  with  children  under  12  months  of  age  usually  work  longer 
hours in the labor market than their non-poor counterparts. Pregnant women and mothers with 
higher incomes work less and have a greater ability to take time off to seek health services. For 
ethnic minority women in the Central Highlands, opportunity costs are much higher.

Gender and the Public Health Sector 

1. 

Division of Labor 

 

7. 
More than half of the labor force in the public health sector in the Central Highlands is 
comprised of women, with the largest in Lam Dong at 63%. In Gia Lai and Kon Tum, about 59% 
of the labor force in the public health sector for each of the provinces are women. In Dak Lak, 
the  estimate  is  60%.  The  gender  division  of  labor  within  the  public  health  sector  is  clearly 
defined based on qualifications and professional skill. Female health workers usually have fewer 
qualifications, and work as nurses, midwives, or administrative staff. In Kon Tum, about 78% of 
untrained  staff,  61%  of  those  with  lower  secondary  education,  and  67%  of  those  with  primary 
school education are women. About 13% of health workers with postgraduate degrees and 26% 
of doctors are women.  
 
Further education and skills training are limited for female health workers because of (i) 
8. 
long  distances  to  training  centers,  (ii)  high  costs  of  training,  (iii)  inability  to  pass  entry-level 
examinations, and (iv) household duties and responsibilities. Female health workers often rely 
on family assistance or preferential quotas to further their education and/or improve their skills. 
There  are  few  incentives  for  female  health  workers,  especially  female  doctors  specialized  in 
obstetrics,  to  work  in  remote  health  facilities.  While  unmarried  women  worry  about  not  finding 
suitable spouses in remote areas, married women are more concerned about the quality of life 
and education for their families in isolated areas.

minorities,  and  women.  The  Project  will  train  new  and  existing  staff  to  ensure  that  ethnic

Economic and Fiscal Sustainability of the Project 

 
14. 
Project  Poverty  Focus.  The  Project's  classification  of  core  poverty  reduction  is  fully 
justified. The region is one of the poorest in Viet Nam.6 The Project is specifically targeting the 
needs  of  the  poor,  especially  ethnic  minorities,  with  its  focus  on  health  financing,  on  district 
health  centers  in  poor  districts,  and  its  support  to  training,  IEC,  and  preventative  care.  The 
Project's investment in civil works and equipment is in districts with poverty rates well above the 
national  average.  The  Project's  support  of  preventative  care  focuses  on  diseases  that  largely 
affect the poor: tuberculosis, malaria, and leprosy. The support to HCFP is already targeted and 
will only benefit the poor and ethnic minorities. 
 
D. 
 
There are two issues regarding project sustainability. The first is whether provinces can 
15. 
provide  funds  to  operate  and  maintain  project  investments  and  hire  new  staff.  The  second  is 
whether HCFP is sustainable, largely a national issue.  
 
Project  Sustainability.  The  financial  sustainability  analysis  is  based  on  conservative 
16. 
assumptions  of  an  increase  in  recurrent  costs  due  to  the  Project.  These  assumptions  include 
operation  and  maintenance  spending  equal  to  10%  of  the  value  of  capital  investment.  The 
Project will also lead to an increase in the number of staff hired, as well as other costs that have 
been factored into the analysis. 
 
17. 
The main source of the public health financing for the four provinces is the state budget. 
Nationally, it accounts for about 50% of the funding support to the health sector, although that 
percentage is higher in the Central Highlands. An estimated 70% of the budget is allocated to 
financing recurrent costs. The Government has increased public health spending since the early 
1990s  by  about  13%  annually  in  real  terms.  The  analysis  assumes  that  provincial  budgets 
increase by 10%, below the historic trend.

Sustainability of HCFP. The sustainability of the health sector depends critically on the 
successful  implementation  and  financing  of  HCFP.  The  Government  has  shown  ownership  of 
HCFP by fully financing the first full year of operation at a cost of around $50 million.  
 
21. 
Analysis shows that the financing burden of the HCFP for the provinces is minimal. The 
real  provincial  budget  for  health  is  projected  to  be  53%  higher  in  2010  than  in  2002.  This 
suggests  that  provincial  health  funding  should  be  sufficient  in  2010  not  only  to  cover  direct 
HCFP  financing  requirements  but  also  to  cover  the  indirect  costs  of  providing  substantially 
higher  levels  of  health  services  to  HCFP  beneficiaries.  HCFP  is  likely  to  be  sustainable 
nationally by 2010.  
 
22. 
HCFP are also likely to be sustainable in the Central Highlands provinces by 2010, if not 
earlier. There will be a drop in provincial health financing for other uses when HCFP operations 
begin in 2003, but the pre-HCFP levels of provincial state budget health funding are likely to be 
exceeded as early as 2004 in Lam Dong, by 2005 in Kon Tum, and by 2006 in Dak Lak and Gia 
Lai.  By  2010,  provincial  health  funding  per  capita  that  would  be  available  for  other  uses  is 
projected  to  have  increased  by  35%  to  49%  from  pre-HCFP  levels  in  the  project  provinces. 
These increased levels of provincial health funding should be sufficient to cover not only each 
province’s  share  of  the  direct  HCFP  financing  burden  but  also  the  cost of  providing  increased 
health services to HCFP beneficiaries.
